title: Tom Holland vs the Nativity: NT Wright answers all your Tom Holland questions
description:
Was Jesus really born in Bethlehem, or did the gospel writers ‚Äúinvent‚Äù the story to fit prophecy? Did a Roman census ever force people to travel back to their ancestral towns? And what about Herod‚Äôs massacre of the innocents ‚Äì pure theology, or plausible history?
In this special Advent episode of¬†Ask NT Wright Anything, Tom Wright and Mike Bird respond to challenges raised by historian Tom Holland (of¬†The Rest Is History¬†podcast) about the birth narratives of Jesus. 

Tom explains why ancient history is full of gaps, how new evidence has repeatedly vindicated biblical details once dismissed as ‚Äúunhistorical,‚Äù and why we should be cautious about confidently declaring, ‚ÄúThat could never have happened.‚Äù

They dig into the census in Luke 2, the translation of the key verse about Quirinius, whether we can trust Matthew‚Äôs account of Herod and the infants, and why early Christians didn‚Äôt simply manufacture stories to ‚Äúfit‚Äù Old Testament prophecy. Along the way, Tom reflects on the place of the virgin conception, why the resurrection is even more central, and how we can hold together faith, history and humility when we read the Christmas stories.

üéß If you‚Äôve ever wondered, ‚ÄúDid Luke get Christmas wrong?‚Äù or felt unsettled by historical objections to the nativity, this episode will help you think more clearly ‚Äì without losing the wonder.

title: Is life meaningless without God? A live school debate between Atheism UK and Christian apologist
description:
In this live edition of Premier Unbelievable? from Aylesbury High School, stand-in host Sam McKee moderates a thought-provoking dialogue between:

Caleb Woodbridge ‚Äì Christian writer, editor and cultural apologist
John Richards ‚Äì President of Atheism UK

Together they wrestle with questions of meaning, value, morality, evolution, human rights, animal ethics, suffering and religion as comfort. Is ‚Äúultimate meaning‚Äù even a coherent idea? If morality evolved, can we still say some values are better than others?

‚è±Ô∏è Chapters 
00:00 ‚Äì Welcome from Aylesbury High School & introductions
01:28 ‚Äì What do we mean by ‚Äúultimate meaning‚Äù?
05:00 ‚Äì Is meaning just human-made value?
08:30 ‚Äì Do we need a ‚Äúmeaning-giver‚Äù beyond ourselves?
12:00 ‚Äì Human rights, slavery & objective moral values
16:00 ‚Äì Evolution, empathy and why we care about others
20:00 ‚Äì Are Christians responsible for moral progress‚Ä¶ or atrocities?
24:00 ‚Äì Animal rights, human rights & species loyalty
28:00 ‚Äì Can we rank values as ‚Äúbetter‚Äù or ‚Äúmore civilised‚Äù?
31:00 ‚Äì When life collapses: is turning to God illusion or contact with reality?
35:00 ‚Äì Does God communicate clearly? Scripture, culture and interpretation
39:00 ‚Äì Thousands of religions: why think the Christian God gives true meaning?
43:00 ‚Äì Audience Q&A and closing reflections

This episode asks whether our deepest experiences of love, beauty, justice and purpose are just products of nature, or signposts to a transcendent source of meaning.

Can atheism justify calling some values ‚Äúbetter‚Äù or ‚Äúmore humane‚Äù? Does Christian belief offer real contact with ultimate reality, or just a comforting story?

If you‚Äôre interested in atheism vs Christianity, meaning of life, and where morality comes from, this conversation is for you.

title: Nigel Biggar on Christianity, Politics, Free Speech & the Future of the West
description:
Lord Nigel Biggar joins Premier Unbelievable? ‚Äì The Interview  host Luke Martin for a wide-ranging conversation on Christianity, politics, and the moral foundations of Western society. A priest in the Church of England, Emeritus Regius Professor of Moral Theology at Oxford, and now a Conservative peer in the House of Lords, Biggar has become one of the UK‚Äôs most prominent public intellectuals.
We discuss his controversial work on colonialism and reparations, the rise of cancel culture and threats to academic freedom, and why he believes free speech is essential to a humane civilisation. Biggar also reflects on assisted dying legislation, Christian engagement in politics, the culture wars, and whether the West is facing civilisational decline.
An unflinching but unmissable interview with one of Britain‚Äôs leading ethicists on truth, courage, and public life.

title: Decoding the Cosmos: Atheist vs Christian on Fine-Tuning, Time, Incarnation & Alien Life
description:
Can Christian faith survive a scientific age... or even thrive in it?

In this special Advent episode of Unbelievable?, host Andy Kind welcomes philosopher of religion Dr Emily Qureshi-Hurst and scientist-theologian Sam McKee for a rich, surprisingly festive exploration of cosmos, time, incarnation and meaning.

Drawing on Emily‚Äôs acclaimed new book Decoding the Cosmos, the trio discuss cosmic fine-tuning, the limits of science, the multiverse, and whether physics points us toward or away from God. 
They then tackle deeper questions: Could there be multiple incarnations? Would alien intelligences need salvation? How might the block-universe theory reshape Christian thinking on resurrection and eternity?

Enjoy today's thoughtful, generous conversation between an atheist philosopher and a Christian academic, perfect for anyone interested in science, faith and the mysteries of existence.

Can theology keep pace with cosmology and evolution?
And does scientific discovery threaten faith, or deepen it?

Subscribe for more intelligent conversations every week.

title: What was John the Baptist doing when he baptised Jews before Jesus‚Äô ministry began? Ask NT Wright
description:
Do ordained ministers have ‚Äúmore‚Äù of the Holy Spirit than lay people? What exactly was John the Baptist doing when he baptised Jews before Jesus‚Äô ministry began? And are the Thirty-Nine Articles still fit for purpose today?

Tom Wright and Mike Bird tackle three questions that sit at the heart of church life, theology, and Christian identity in today's episode of Ask NT Wright Anything.

Tom explains why ordination is not about spiritual hierarchy but authorised service, why the Holy Spirit belongs fully to the whole people of God, and how clergy exist to equip, not outrank, the church. He then situates John the Baptist firmly within Israel‚Äôs story of exile and hope, showing how baptism functioned as a powerful symbol of repentance and new Exodus rather than an early version of Christian conversion. Finally, Tom reflects candidly on the Thirty-Nine Articles of the Church of England: why they were written, what they were trying to hold together, and why many of their answers belong to 16th-century debates rather than today‚Äôs questions.

Throughout the conversation, Tom calls the church back to Scripture as the supreme authority, urges humility toward our theological inheritance, and reminds us that reform is not rejection‚Äîbut faithful listening across time.

Q1 01:43      Do Clergy Have More of the Holy Spirit?
Q2 12:28    What exactly was John the Baptist doing when he baptised Jews before Jesus‚Äô ministry began?         
Q3 18:31      Are the Thirty-Nine Articles still fit for purpose today?

title: Why doesn‚Äôt the Bible punish men for adultery? Ask NT Wright Anything Podcast
description:
Why does the Old Testament sometimes appear to treat women unfairly in cases of adultery? What was the purpose of the Nazirite vow, and why would anyone choose it? And what does it really mean to say that Christ is ‚Äúpresent‚Äù in the Eucharist?

Today, Tom Wright and Mike Bird dive in on Ask NT Wright Anything to answer your three challenging and deeply human questions about law, holiness, and sacrament. Tom explores how Israel‚Äôs legal codes functioned within their ancient social world, how Jesus radically reframes judgment and mercy, and why Christians no longer apply Old Testament penalties in the same way. He then reflects on the Nazirite vow as an ancient form of radical consecration, an Israelite counterpart to later monastic devotion. 

Throughout, Tom insists that Scripture must be read as a coherent story rather than isolated proof texts, and that Christian faith is shaped not by abstract theories but by lived practices: meals, vows, forgiveness, and embodied worship.

Q1  00:44  What should I make of the lack of consequence for the men involved in adultery, compared to the public humiliation of women, via the cursed water, whether they did it or not?
Q2  01:10  Why would anyone choose to be a Nazarite? What did it mean to them?
Q3  13:29  Is Jesus actually present in the Eucharist?

title: Where is the Garden of Eden? NT Wright on Genesis, editing & authority
description:
Where is the Garden of Eden? What did Paul mean by our ‚Äúearthly tent‚Äù? And does Genesis contain later edits, and if so, does that undermine Scripture? In this episode of¬†Ask NT Wright Anything, Tom Wright and Mike Bird tackle three of the most frequently misunderstood biblical questions.

Tom explains why Paul‚Äôs language in 2 Corinthians 5 isn‚Äôt Platonic escapism but robust resurrection hope; why the ‚Äútent‚Äù points both to the tabernacle and to our mortal bodies; and how the early Christians understood ‚Äúwhat is kept in heaven‚Äù as something destined ultimately¬†for earth.

Next, they turn to the location of Eden, and Tom challenges the assumption that Genesis 2 must read like Google Maps. They explore how ancient narrative works, what editing does (and does¬†not) mean for inspiration, and why Genesis 1‚Äì2 gives us two complementary windows into creation, not a modern-style chronology.

Q1  02:08    In 2 Corinthians 5:1 Paul writes about the 'Earthly Tent' - what is Paul actually describing? Is this an intermediate state?
Q2: 11:28     In Genesis 2 we see the location of Eden - but where is Eden actually? Was this passage edited later in history and if so, how does this affect reading and accuracy of Scripture?

If you‚Äôve ever wondered whether Genesis has contradictions, whether Paul believed in an intermediate state, or whether Scripture‚Äôs ‚Äúoddities‚Äù weaken its authority, this episode will steady the ground beneath your feet, and deepen your appreciation for the beauty, richness, and layered texture of the biblical story.

title: Is Jesus the Messiah? Rabbi Shapiro vs Christian Scholar on Isaiah 53 & Prophecy
description:
Did Jesus fulfil Old Testament prophecy? A Rabbi and a Christian scholar debate Isaiah 53, Bethlehem, the virgin birth, and the identity of the Messiah.

Host John Nelson brings together two sharp minds for a respectful yet fiery conversation: Dr Johnny Rowlands (Christian Professor at St Mellitus College) and Rabbi Prof Marc Shapiro (of the University of Scranton). 

The big question in today's conversation is: whether Scripture predicted the Messiah, or whether the Messiah reshaped how Scripture was understood.

If you‚Äôre interested in Jewish‚ÄìChristian dialogue, biblical prophecy, or the historical Jesus, this episode is for you.

04:45 Are there really 300 Messianic prophecies?

39:45 Myth, History & how the Gospels use Scripture
58:45 ‚ÄúAccording to the Scriptures:‚Äù Cross & Resurrection

üîç Key Topics in This Debate
Isaiah 53: Suffering servant: Messiah or Israel?

Different Jewish and Christian hermeneutics

title: Demons in the New Testament? Is Saturday the 'real' Sabbath? and when did 'high church' become cool?
description:
Demonic activity in the New Testament, the surprising rise of ‚Äúhigh church‚Äù worship, and whether Christians should be keeping Saturday as the Sabbath‚Ä¶
This week on¬†Ask NT Wright Anything, Tom and Mike tackle three big and very different questions. 
First:¬†Did Jesus‚Äô arrival trigger a surge in demonic activity, and should Christians today expect to encounter the demonic?¬†Tom draws on decades of pastoral experience (including licensed diocesan exorcists!) to explain how the New Testament frames dark spiritual powers and why neither fear nor fascination is the right Christian response.

Next, they explore why so many young Christians are moving toward ‚Äúhigh church‚Äù traditions‚Äîliturgy, sacrament, structure, and beauty, and how to discern wisely between Anglican, Lutheran, Methodist, Catholic, and low-church evangelical expressions.

Finally, Tom unpacks the Sabbath controversy:¬†If the Bible commands Sabbath on the seventh day, why do Christians worship on Sunday?¬†What changed between the Old and New Testaments? And should we still keep a weekly day of rest in a Sabbatarian sense?
Another rich episode (we hope!) full of biblical grounding, pastoral wisdom, and Tom‚Äôs signature clarity.

title: Is It Rational to Believe in God? Christian Philosopher vs Humanist in Epic School Debate
description:
Is belief in God¬†rational, or is it something no reasonable person should accept?
In this live¬†Unbelievable?¬†school debate recorded in Sir Henry Floyd Grammar School in Aylesbury,¬†Andy Kind¬†hosts philosopher¬†Dr Joshua Sijuwade (University of Birmingham) and physician-educator¬†Julius Weinberg¬†(Trustee, National Secular Society) for a rigorous and fiery exchange on the¬†sanity of belief.
0:00 ‚Äì Welcome to Unbelievable at School: Is Belief in God Sane?
0:49 ‚Äì Reasonable vs Rational: Josh Sijuwade Explains the Difference
2:51 ‚Äì Julius Weinberg‚Äô Fallibilism: Why He Tries Not to ‚ÄúBelieve‚Äù Anything
6:01 ‚Äì Is It Rational to Believe in God at All?
10:26 ‚Äì Which God Are We Talking About? Defining the Divine
13:34 ‚Äì The Big Objection: If God Is Good, Why So Much Suffering?
15:39 ‚Äì Josh‚Äôs Answer: Suffering, Moral Growth & ‚ÄúExemplar‚Äù Souls
19:40 ‚Äì ‚ÄúProfoundly Unpleasant‚Äù: Julius Pushes Back on the Theodicy
24:50 ‚Äì Couldn‚Äôt a Perfect God Make a World Without Pain?
31:10 ‚Äì Do We Need God to Explain Suffering and Nature?
35:26 ‚Äì What Evidence Is There for God? Cosmology, Design & Consciousness
39:47 ‚Äì Final Exchanges & Closing Thoughts

#GodDebate #AtheistVsChristian #RationalFaith #ProblemOfEvil #DoesGodExist

They tackle some of the biggest questions in philosophy of religion:
What does it¬†mean¬†for a belief to be rational? Can we ever be justified in believing in God? Is fallibilism the only sane epistemic stance? Does suffering make God impossible?Can moral courage, compassion and virtue exist in a world without pain?And what evidence ‚Äî if any ‚Äî points to a divine being? From epistemology and Bayesian reasoning to the¬†problem of evil,¬†moral exemplars,¬†consciousness,¬†cosmology, and whether God is even a¬†good¬†explanation, this robust debate will challenge believers and skeptics alike.
Don't miss today's fast-paced, high-level, and rather entertaining discussion for anyone curious about how reason, doubt, and faith intersect.

title: Is ‚Äúbiblical womanhood‚Äù really biblical ‚Äì or mostly cultural? Historian Beth Allison Barr Responds
description:
In this episode of Premier Unbelievable: The Interview, Luke Martin sits down with medieval historian and pastor‚Äôs wife Professor Beth Allison Barr (Baylor University) to talk about women‚Äôs leadership in the church, complementarianism vs egalitarianism, and the hidden history of female ministry.

Beth shares her journey from committed complementarian to vocal critic, the heavy personal cost of speaking out, and why she believes ‚Äúbiblical manhood and womanhood‚Äù owe more to patriarchy than to Scripture. Drawing on her expertise in medieval church history, she explores how women have preached, led house churches and even held ordained roles across the centuries ‚Äì long before modern feminism.

0:00 ‚Äì Introduction

0:32 ‚Äì Meet Professor Beth Allison Barr
Beth introduces herself, her work at Baylor, and her books.

1:46 ‚Äì Beth‚Äôs Upbringing & Early Faith
Growing up in Texas, childhood faith, and her call to ministry and scholarship.

3:08 ‚Äì Becoming a Medieval Historian
Why Beth chose medieval history and her fascination with women in the medieval church.

5:55 ‚Äì What Drives Beth‚Äôs Work
The through-line of her scholarship: women‚Äôs roles, ministry, and historical limits.

7:27 ‚Äì Complementarian vs Egalitarian Explained
Beth outlines the modern debate and how it shapes church and family life.

9:33 ‚Äì Counting the Cost of Speaking Up
The personal and professional risk of publishing The Making of Biblical Womanhood.

12:06 ‚Äì Backlash & Public Criticism
How major ministries responded and the toll it took on Beth and her family.

16:13 ‚Äì Unexpected Success of the Book
NPR, the New Yorker, and a bestselling reception.

18:42 ‚Äì Is ‚ÄúBiblical Womanhood‚Äù Cultural?
Beth‚Äôs core argument: complementarianism reflects cultural patriarchy, not Scripture.

21:01 ‚Äì Marriage, Submission & Paul‚Äôs Teaching
A discussion of Ephesians 5, mutual submission, and early Christian household codes.

24:03 ‚Äì Women Leaders in the Early Church
Junia, Phoebe, Priscilla, and why their leadership roles matter.

27:06 ‚Äì Is Junia Really a Woman?
Beth responds to complementarian attempts to reinterpret Junia.

31:07 ‚Äì Is Egalitarianism Just Feminism?
Beth explains why feminist insights aren‚Äôt the origin of Christian egalitarianism.

33:42 ‚Äì What Medieval History Reveals
Surprising evidence of inclusive language and women‚Äôs roles in medieval sermons.

38:03 ‚Äì Women‚Äôs Ordination in Church History
A dive into medieval ordination, abbesses, preaching, and shifting theological views.

43:01 ‚Äì How Should Christians Relate to Feminism?
Beth‚Äôs answer to fears around ‚Äúthe f-word‚Äù in evangelical spaces.

44:52 ‚Äì Becoming the Pastor‚Äôs Wife (The New Book)
Why Beth wrote it and how pastor‚Äôs wives shaped complementarianism.

47:06 ‚Äì Beth‚Äôs Shift Away from Complementarianism
The decade-long journey: scholarship, church experience, and conscience.

50:01 ‚Äì Why Complementarianism Hurts Everyone
Impacts on boys, girls, and a connection to abuse scandals.

53:17 ‚Äì Is Leadership a Burden?
Responding to the idea that male headship imposes hardship on men.

56:25 ‚Äì A System That Can Go Wrong
Why good marriages don‚Äôt erase theological problems; the story of Maria.

1:00:26 ‚Äì Submission in Christian Life
Why Beth affirms mutual submission but rejects gender-fixed authority.

1:04:20 ‚Äì Living Beyond the Curse
Genesis, the fall, and why Beth sees complementarianism as rooted in the fall, not creation.

1:05:57 ‚Äì Beth‚Äôs Hope for Her Legacy
The moving story of a student who said the book ‚Äúgave me back my Jesus.‚Äù

1:08:51 ‚Äì What Beth Is Writing Next
A new book on medieval women‚Äôs ministry‚Äîand then a long break.

1:10:00 ‚Äì Closing Thoughts & Upcoming Events
Final reflections and Beth‚Äôs Greenbelt appearance.

üìö Books by Beth Allison Barr mentioned in this episode:

The Making of Biblical Womanhood: How the Subjugation of Women Became Gospel Truth https://amzn.to/41E8fYr and Becoming the Pastor‚Äôs Wife: How Marriage Replaced Ordination as a Woman‚Äôs Path to Ministry   https://amzn.to/4mX8vtG

Beth Allison Barr¬†(PhD, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill), a¬†New York Times¬†and¬†USA Today¬†bestselling author, is James Vardaman Professor of History at Baylor University in Waco, Texas, where she specialises in medieval history, women's history, and church history.

title: Is Online Church Really Church? N.T. Wright on Models of Church, the Lord‚Äôs Prayer & New Age Faith
description:
Is online church really church? Why do Christians add ‚ÄúFor thine is the kingdom, the power and the glory‚Äù to the Lord‚Äôs Prayer when it isn‚Äôt in the earliest manuscripts? And have New Age practices‚Äîlike mindfulness, energy work or quasi-spiritual meditation‚Äîslipped quietly into modern Christian life?

In this episode of Ask N.T. Wright Anything, world-renowned Bible scholar Tom Wright joins Mike Bird to take on three listener questions about church life, biblical text, and spiritual discernment.

1:52 Q1 ‚Äì Are our church services real Christian community?

‚õ™ 1. What is the real church?
Tom and Mike explore the gap between the service-centred Western model and the New Testament vision of daily, embodied community. They also ask whether livestream services and ‚Äúonline church‚Äù can ever be a genuine substitute for gathering in person.

üôè 2. Why do we add ‚ÄúFor thine is the kingdom‚Ä¶‚Äù?
The Lord‚Äôs Prayer often ends with a line that many modern Bibles don‚Äôt include. Tom explains the history, manuscript evidence, early church liturgy, and why Christians still pray this doxology today.

‚ú® 3. Has New Age spirituality infiltrated Christianity?
From mindfulness to meditation apps to ‚Äúfinding the goddess within,‚Äù the hosts discuss where Christian spiritual practice overlaps with wider culture‚Äîand where it crosses dangerous lines.

If you‚Äôre interested in biblical studies, church practice, theology, New Age spirituality, scripture reliability, or Christian discipleship, this episode is packed with clarity and insight.

title: Was Peter Really the Rock? Did Mary Stay a Virgin? | N.T. Wright Answers Your Questions
description:
Ask N.T. Wright Anything: Precision in Faith, Peter the Rock, and the Virgin Birth

In this episode Mike Bird and NT Wright tackle three major theological questions.

First, a listener from Ohio asks how precise our beliefs need to be in order to be ‚Äúsaved‚Äù. Tom reframes salvation away from the idea of ‚Äúgoing to heaven when you die‚Äù and towards the biblical vision of God‚Äôs new creation and the defeat of death. They discuss Romans 10, baptism, assurance, and why Christian faith is about trusting Jesus rather than mastering perfect doctrine.

Next, they look at Matthew 16 and ask: Is Peter himself the rock, or is the rock his confession that Jesus is the Messiah? Tom explores early interpretations and how this passage functions within the wider New Testament.

Finally, they take on the significance of the virgin birth‚Äîwhat Isaiah 7:14 really meant, why first-century Jews weren‚Äôt expecting a virgin-born Messiah, the difference from pagan ‚Äúdivine birth‚Äù myths, and how the story points to God‚Äôs grace, the initiative of the Trinity, and Jesus‚Äô true humanity received from Mary.

0:00 ‚Äì Intro & Ohio/Birmingham banter
1:10 ‚Äì Q1: How precise does faith need to be to be ‚Äúsaved‚Äù?
10:39 ‚Äì Q2: Is Peter really ‚Äúthe rock‚Äù in Matthew 16?
18:50 ‚Äì Q3: Why was Jesus born of a virgin?
33:44 ‚Äì Did Mary remain a virgin after Jesus‚Äô birth?

title: Inside Pastor Tim Keller‚Äôs Mind: Kathy Keller on Sin, Idolatry & Today‚Äôs Crisis
description:
‚ÄúSin is the last taboo.‚Äù
Kathy Keller joins Luke Martin for one of the most personal and revealing conversations ever recorded about faith, grief, idolatry, and the theological ideas she shared with her late husband, Tim Keller.

Kathy reflects on growing up bookish in Pittsburgh, discovering C.S. Lewis as a teenager ‚Äì and even writing to him, receiving several personal letters that shaped her early Christian life. She also opens up about the thinkers who most influenced Tim‚Äôs preaching: John Owen, Jonathan Edwards, Herman Bavinck, Tolkien, Packer, Stott and more.

A major theme of the interview is sin, which Kathy calls ‚Äúthe last taboo‚Äù in modern culture. Drawing on Tim‚Äôs posthumous book What Is Wrong with the World?, she explains how sin disguises itself, how idolatry takes root in every heart, and why facing our brokenness is essential for understanding God‚Äôs grace.

We also hear moving reflections on Kathy‚Äôs marriage to Tim, the shock of losing him, and the painful discovery of the idols we never knew we had ‚Äî alongside her conviction that ‚ÄúYou were built to run on God.‚Äù

description:
In this episode, Tom Wright and Mike Bird field three big listener questions that touch the heart of Christian hope and daily discipleship.

First, they explore¬†what happens when we die¬†‚Äî where do our loved ones go before the final resurrection? Tom explains what Scripture actually says (and doesn‚Äôt say) about ‚Äúsouls,‚Äù ‚Äúheaven,‚Äù and ‚Äúwaiting rooms for the dead,‚Äù and why our hope is not escape from earth but¬†the renewal of creation itself.

Next, they reflect on¬†whether we will know everything in the new creation, and how knowledge, love, and transformation intertwine in God‚Äôs future.
Finally, they turn to¬†biblical budgeting, asking how Christians in affluent societies can honour God with their money without being ruled by it.
It‚Äôs an episode that spans heaven and earth; we hope you'll find this a dive into theology, that's thoughtful, practical, and full of hope.

description:

They begin by exploring the mystery of¬†who wrote the Letter to the Hebrews, unpacking why the early church left the author anonymous and how that shapes our reading today. 
Next, they move to a deeply sensitive and much-debated topic ‚Äî¬†who goes to hell¬†‚Äî where Tom challenges popular misconceptions about eternal punishment and invites listeners to rediscover the biblical vision of judgment, mercy, and renewal. Finally, they take on the¬†question of the canon, asking whether Christians should read only the 66 books of the Protestant Bible or include the wider writings Tom often references in his work.
From authorship debates to eschatology and biblical interpretation, this episode blends deep theology with pastoral wisdom, offering clarity and compassion in equal measure.

title: Beyond Naturalism: What‚Äôs Real?¬†Dr. Alex Carter vs Dr. Zachary Ardern - Hosted by Sam McKee
description:
What is¬†really¬†real? In this wide-ranging conversation,¬†Dr Zachary Ardern¬†(evolutionary biologist, Wellcome Sanger Institute),¬†Dr Alex Carter¬†(philosopher, University of Cambridge), and¬†Dr Sam McKee¬†(science historian, Manchester Metropolitan University) sit down¬†to revisit one of the oldest debates in human thought ‚Äî the relationship between science, religion, and ultimate reality.

From the¬†Scopes Trial¬†to the¬†Big Bang, from¬†naturalism¬†to¬†theism, the panel wrestles with big questions:
‚Äì Are science and faith speaking different languages?
‚Äì Does scientific success make religion obsolete?
‚Äì Can naturalism explain consciousness and morality?
‚Äì Is the universe just matter in motion ‚Äî or does it point beyond itself?

This one will get you thinking and may even surprise you in their discussion about meaning, knowledge, and the limits of what science can tell us.

title: Help N.T. Wright! Please clarify salvation
description:
Today on the¬†Ask NT Wright Anything Podcast, Mike Bird and Tom Wright tackle three challenging listener questions that get to the heart of Christian theology and biblical imagination.
Should we pray for Satan?¬†Tom unpacks how centuries of Christian mythology have distorted biblical ideas of ‚Äúthe Satan‚Äù (the accuser), explaining why evil has no rightful place in God‚Äôs good creation,and what it really means when Scripture says Jesus ‚Äúdisarmed the powers.‚Äù
Next, the pair discuss¬†Jesus‚Äô words to the thief on the cross ‚Äî ‚ÄúToday you will be with me in paradise.‚Äù¬†What does ‚Äúparadise‚Äù actually mean in the Bible? Tom draws on ancient language and early church thought to clarify the difference between¬†‚Äúlife after death‚Äù¬†and¬†‚Äúlife after life after death‚Äù, showing how the Spirit sustains believers in Christ‚Äôs presence until the resurrection.
And our last question today is on the life of purification: what it means for God to prune and refine us, not as punishment but as preparation for holiness and fruitfulness. Tom uses the image of pruning from John 15 to remind us that when God cuts things away, He is often closest to us.

01:19 Should we pray for Satan ‚Äî and his repentance?
10:23 What does ‚ÄúToday you will be with me in Paradise‚Äù really mean about salvation?

title: Science, Faith & AI: What‚Äôs the Best Explanation for Reality? | Paul Ewart & Simon Walker-Samuel
description:
What does it mean to be human in a universe of atoms, AI and possible aliens? In this lively and good-humoured conversation, two leading physicists go head-to-head on science, religion and the nature of reality.

Professor Paul Ewart (Oxford University, former Chair of Christians in Science) and Professor Simon Walker-Samuel (UCL, trustee of Humanists UK, pioneer in AI-driven cancer research) join Dr Sam McKee at John Colet School, UK.
00:00 Science vs Religion & Reality ‚Äî Intro 
01:00 Meet the speakers ‚Äî Oxford atomic physics & UCL biophysics
03:00 AI in medicine ‚Äî digital twins, biophysics & personalised cancer care
05:00 What is Humanism? Humanism vs atheism explained
07:00 Can empathy, art & morality be explained by evolution?
10:30 How science works ‚Äî models, assumptions & limits
12:30 ‚ÄúGod of the gaps‚Äù or complementarity? Science & faith
14:30 Evidence vs proof ‚Äî can we test or measure God?
16:00 Are we more than atoms? Consciousness, mind & emergence
24:30 Meaning & purpose ‚Äî why is there ‚Äúsomething rather than nothing‚Äù?
30:00 Will technology & AI replace religion?
31:30 Science, secularisation & society (US vs Europe)
33:30 Christianity‚Äôs impact ‚Äî human rights, abolition & Tom Holland‚Äôs ‚ÄúDominion‚Äù
35:30 Reductionism vs emergence ‚Äî can love be explained by physics?
38:00 Audience Q&A begins
39:00 Does faith motivate scientific research?
40:00 Can we build instruments to detect the divine?
42:00 Fine-tuning of the universe ‚Äî anthropic principle vs design
44:00 Was intelligent life inevitable?
45:00 Are aliens real? Life beyond Earth, NASA/JPL & astrobiology
48:00 Salvation & seeking God ‚Äî what if I never find faith?
50:00 Wrap-up & thanks

Together, they tackle:

Can science explain everything?

Is consciousness more than the brain?

Does morality require God?

Are love and meaning just chemical reactions?

What happens when AI becomes more like us?

A thoughtful, respectful exchange for classrooms, curious minds and lifelong learners.

title: Can Christianity Save Democracy?¬†Os Guinness v Jonathan Rauch hosted by Vince Vitale
description:
Can Christianity help rescue a divided democracy‚Äîor is religion part of the problem?
Host Vince Vitale moderates a timely exchange between Jonathan Rauch (author of Cross Purposes: Christianity‚Äôs Broken Bargain with Democracy) and Os Guinness (author of America Agonistes).

Rauch‚Äîonce an ‚Äúapatheist‚Äù‚Äînow argues that liberal democracy needs Christianity‚Äôs moral spine. Guinness agrees that faith undergirds freedom, while warning against both politicised religion and post-religious power politics. Together they discuss truth, forgiveness, civic virtue, and how to rebuild public trust.

Key moments

Rauch‚Äôs ‚Äúthree Christian principles‚Äù he says sustain democracy

Guinness apologises for how some Christians have treated Rauch (and for the Church‚Äôs record of antisemitism)

Practical next steps for people of faith and secular neighbours

title: Does Science Make God Unnecessary?¬†Alex Carter vs Zachary Ardern hosted by Andy Kind
description:
Does Science make God unnecessary?

In today's¬†Unbelievable?¬†school debate,¬†Zachary Ardern, a christian biologist, and¬†Alex Carter, an atheist scientist, face off on whether scientific progress has made belief in God obsolete. Hosted by Andy Kind and filmed in collaboration with Aylesbury Vale Youth For Christ.

Highlights
0:43 ‚Äì Rational vs reasonable (Alex explains the difference)
2:18 ‚Äì Zach‚Äôs opener: why Christian faith can be rational (science & belief)
4:53 ‚Äì Alex: faith as ‚Äúnon-rational‚Äù rather than irrational (Wittgenstein)
9:02 ‚Äì Can faith be personal trust and still be rational?
10:55 ‚Äì Doctrines as events: creation, incarnation, atonement, resurrection
12:10 ‚Äì Plato, Job & meaning without tidy explanations (Alex)
18:05 ‚Äì Science within a theistic framework; Asa Gray & Darwin (Zach)
24:47 ‚Äì Scientism critique; rain-dance vs celebration analogy (Alex)
27:24 ‚Äì Signs that point beyond: empty tomb, fine-tuning, beginnings (Zach)
29:58 ‚Äì Historicity of Scripture: can the Gospels be trusted?
31:48 ‚Äì Skepticism about sources; Plato‚Äôs dialogues & bias (Alex)
34:36 ‚Äì Faith, doubt and degrees of confidence (both)
35:22 ‚Äì Simone Weil, certainty, and intellectual honesty (Alex)
37:42 ‚Äì Audience Q&A begins
40:02 ‚Äì Q1: God‚Äôs plan, hell & inclusivism/annihilationism (Zach; Alex adds Lewis)
44:07 ‚Äì Q2: Problem of evil‚Äîapologetics vs consolation (Alex; Zach responds)
49:54 ‚Äì Wrap-up & credits (applause)

Can science explain everything, or does it point beyond itself? Is faith irrational in the age of reason?What counts as evidence for God?Are morality and meaning possible without a creator?From the fine-tuning of the universe to the limits of human understanding, Zach and Alex debate whether God remains the best explanation, or whether naturalism is more than enough to disprove the existence of a God. What do you think?

Dr Zachary Ardern is an Evolutionary Biologist at a research institute in Cambridge.
Dr Alex Carter is the Academic Director for Philosophy and Interdisciplinary Studies at the University of Cambridge, Institute of Continuing Education.

Bollor√©, co-author of Bestselling, God: The Science, The Evidence, argues that twentieth-century discoveries - from thermodynamics and entropy to expansion and fine-tuning‚Äîstack up as evidence for a Creator. 

They test ‚Äúbeginning versus eternity,‚Äù debate whether fine-tuning signals design or selection effects, and ask what constitutes prediction, falsifiability, and proof. Is the ‚ÄúGod hypothesis‚Äù scientific, metaphysical, or both? Can science ever answer ‚Äúwhy there is something rather than nothing‚Äù? 

Thoughtful, spirited, and friendly, this episode brings faith and physics into constructive dialogue.

title: Hell: The Debate That Won‚Äôt Go Away | Dan Paterson v Jordan Wood hosted by Vince Vitale
description:
Few topics raise as many questions as hell. Is it eternal torment, final destruction, or something else entirely? In this episode of Premier Unbelievable?, Vince Vitale is joined by Australian apologist Dan Paterson (Questioning Christianity: Is There More to the Story?) and Catholic theologian Jordan Wood (The Whole Mystery of Christ). Together they explore whether the traditional doctrine of Eternal Conscious Torment is biblically and theologically defensible, and why so many Christians today are reconsidering alternative views such as conditional immortality or annihilationism.
00:00 ‚Äì Intro & setup: What is hell and why does it matter?
00:12 ‚Äì Framing the debate: What *is* hell, really?
02:32 ‚Äì Three major views: ECT, Conditionalism & Universalism
04:50 ‚Äì Dan‚Äôs case: ‚ÄúThe fire *destroys* body and soul‚Äù
05:02 ‚Äì Jordan‚Äôs case: Hell as the ‚Äúdoor locked from the inside‚Äù
06:26 ‚Äì Jordan: A restorative *universalism* (with real judgment)
11:07 ‚Äì The Fatherhood challenge: Could love will eternal torment?
13:06 ‚Äì Dan‚Äôs journey: From eternal torment to conditional immortality
23:01 ‚Äì Jordan‚Äôs Revelation argument: The ‚Äúkings‚Äù return in Rev 21
29:00 ‚Äì Dan pushes back: New rulers, not restored rebels
31:15 ‚Äì Dan‚Äôs key claim: Scripture contrasts *life* vs *destruction*
34:44 ‚Äì Two paths only? No ‚Äúdestruction-then-salvation‚Äù
36:00 ‚Äì Post-mortem repentance? Jordan says yes
37:06 ‚Äì Dan‚Äôs warning: Parables teach *finality*
49:12 ‚Äì Both steel-man their own weaknesses
55:59 ‚Äì If they‚Äôre wrong‚Ä¶ which view they‚Äôd prefer
1:04:02 ‚Äì Dan: ‚ÄúHell should make us weep‚Äù
1:07:05 ‚Äì Jordan: ‚ÄúPerfect love casts out fear‚Äù

Dan and Jordan unpack historical perspectives, scriptural exegesis, and philosophical concerns, while also asking why the question of hell matters so much for evangelism and apologetics in a suffering-filled world. Is hell a cosmic torture chamber, or the tragic end of rejecting God‚Äôs love? Join us for a thoughtful, challenging conversation on one of Christianity‚Äôs hardest teachings.

description:
The shocking death of Charlie Kirk has left a void in the public square. In this week's show Premier Unbelievable?'s Billy Hallowell is joined by Os Guinness and Krish Kandiah to reflect on Kirk‚Äôs legacy, the controversies, and the reckoning his loss demands. How do we preserve free speech without fear? How do we turn down the temperature in our debates? And can we recover the art of disagreeing agreeably in a polarised age? Charlie Kirk was a figure unafraid to step into hostile spaces, defend his Christian faith, and face opponents head-on. From the Oxford Union to U.S. campuses, Kirk embodied a willingness to disagree openly at a time when many retreat to echo chambers.

0:00 Intro
0:05 Why this moment matters
2:36 Charlie‚Äôs queue for critics
7:02 When words break down
9:14 Silos, stats & story
25:26 Free speech & the imago Dei
39:03 Hard choices, no easy peace
54:56 How to disagree well
1:04:07 What‚Äôs at stake if we fail
1:07:01 Closing & call to civility

title: Do we have a soul - or are we just bodies and brains? Harry Amos vs Dr Claire Gilbert
description:
In this live edition of¬†Unbelievable?, Andy Kind hosts a fascinating conversation on the nature of the soul and spiritual experience.
Philosopher¬†Harry Amos, a former Christian turned humanist, challenges whether the soul exists at all, pointing to science, consciousness studies, and the limits of dualism. Meanwhile,¬†Dr. Claire Gilbert, writer and ethicist, shares her profound personal journey through faith, ecology, and cancer, drawing inspiration from Julian of Norwich and the deep mysteries of spirit, love, and human worth.

0:00 ‚Äì Opening & welcome
0:12 ‚Äì Today‚Äôs topic: the soul & spiritual experience; guests introduced
0:32 ‚Äì Harry‚Äôs story: from evangelical Christian to humanist
3:05 ‚Äì Claire‚Äôs story: Church of England, Julian of Norwich & theology
5:05 ‚Äì Medical ethics, grief & the limits of ‚Äúpure reason‚Äù
6:23 ‚Äì Cancer diagnosis: learning to face suffering with Julian of Norwich
7:56 ‚Äì Writing from the heart: telling Julian‚Äôs story
8:47 ‚Äì Why the Church‚Äôs ‚Äúdepth‚Äù matters for a thirsty world
9:53 ‚Äì What is a soul? Defining terms & dualism
10:56 ‚Äì Who has the burden of proof? Does the soul explain anything?
13:36 ‚Äì Vitalism analogy; are we re-running an old mistake?
14:55 ‚Äì ‚ÄúWeird physics‚Äù ‚â† the supernatural: relativity, QM, organoids playing Pong
16:44 ‚Äì Qualia & colour: what fMRI reveals about experience
17:51 ‚Äì Claire‚Äôs critique of Enlightenment control & either/or thinking
19:37 ‚Äì Beyond mind/body splits: interconnection, humility, surrender
22:49 ‚Äì ‚ÄúSoul mentoring‚Äù: caring for the inner life of public servants
24:01 ‚Äì Do humans have unique worth? Empathy, value & meaning
28:14 ‚Äì ‚ÄúI care, therefore I am‚Äù: head vs heart
29:28 ‚Äì Argument or art? Why some realities are experienced, not proved
30:01 ‚Äì Do animals have souls? Are we asking the wrong question?
32:49 ‚Äì Hope, love & the non-rational that helps us live
33:49 ‚Äì Sentience vs ‚Äúsoul‚Äù; anthropomorphism (Castaway‚Äôs ‚ÄúWilson‚Äù)
35:45 ‚Äì Q&A starts
35:52 ‚Äì Q1: What happens when you die? (Harry)
37:11 ‚Äì Q1: What happens when you die? (Claire)
39:01 ‚Äì Q2: Will your views on the afterlife change?
41:17 ‚Äì Q3: How do you explain spiritual experiences?
43:00 ‚Äì Music vs sheet music: an analogy for mystical experience
43:29 ‚Äì Silence, contemplation & presence
44:53 ‚Äì Closing & thanks
From neuroscience and quantum mechanics to prayer, mortality, and whether dogs have souls (!), this discussion wrestles with some of the most profound questions humans can ask:

Is the soul real, or just a poetic metaphor?
What happens when we die?
Are spiritual experiences evidence of something beyond matter?
Do concepts like love, hope, and value point us to a reality science alone can‚Äôt explain?
What happens after we die?

title: Should Church Leaders Be Ordained? Are We Needed To Usher In The New Creation
description:
Mike Bird and Tom Wright take on three big listener questions. First: how do we actually cooperate with the Spirit in God‚Äôs plan for new creation? Tom reflects on what it means to anticipate heaven and earth being joined, and how our present faithfulness participates in that future hope. Next: ordination and church leadership. Are we in danger of over-structuring the body of Christ? Drawing from the New Testament and church history, Tom considers why ordination emerged and what it means for today. Finally: egalitarian roots and resurrection hope. Were the earliest churches more like Corinth‚Äôs fluid gatherings? What about para-church movements? And in Revelation 20, what sort of resurrection is Peter really speaking about? Tom explores continuity, community, and the call to live as people of the age to come.

title: Can AI make Moral choices? | Ethics, Sentience & the Future of Artificial Intelligence
description:
In this second part of our Premier Unbelievable? schools debate with Aylesbury Youth or Christ, host Andy Kind is joined once again by philosophers Dr Amna Whiston (Oxford University) and Dr Alex Carter (Cambridge University) to explore the ethical dilemmas raised by artificial intelligence.

Previous show with these guests: Can AI Create or Feel? https://youtu.be/-wCBELHLeMs

What happens when machines are asked to make moral decisions? Can AI ever be truly responsible - or feel pain? What are the risks of outsourcing human judgment to code? And is a "happy dystopia" ruled by AI just around the corner?

Together, they unpack issues like the trolley problem, privacy, intellectual property, moral intuition, and the dehumanising effects of the ‚Äúrace to the middle.‚Äù This thought-provoking conversation asks not just what AI can do, but what it might undo in human society.

title: Why does a 'Good God' allow Suffering and Evil?¬†Dr Joshua Sijuwade vs Dr Stephen Law
description:
If God is all-powerful and all-loving, why does so much evil exist?
In this edition of¬†Unbelievable?, Christian philosopher¬†Dr. Joshua Sijuwade¬†debates atheist philosopher¬†Dr. Stephen Law¬†on whether the reality of suffering undermines belief in God‚Äîor whether there are good reasons a loving God might allow it.
From¬†moral evil¬†and¬†natural disasters¬†to the¬†evil God challenge¬†and the limits of human understanding, the discussion dives deep into one of philosophy‚Äôs most enduring and emotionally charged questions.

title: Can AI Create or Feel? Dr Amna Whiston & Dr Alex Carter debate Human vs Artificial Intelligence
description:
What does it really mean to think, create, or feel? Are we losing our humanity in the age of AI - or discovering it anew? In this live schools debate with Aylesbury Youth For Christ, Premier Unbelievable? host Andy Kind is joined by Dr Amna Whiston (Oxford) and Dr Alex Carter (Cambridge) to explore the limits of artificial intelligence. Together they ask: Can machines ever truly be creative? Can they experience emotion - or are they just mirroring us back to ourselves?

2:58 ‚Äì Can machines create if they can‚Äôt feel?

Expect a lively, thoughtful and sometimes humorous conversation on philosophy of mind, the uncanny valley, whether AI can be conscious, and what separates humans from code. In this explosive end-of-term schools debate, Unbelievable? host Andy Kind moderates a gripping clash between Christian evangelist and CEO of Speak Life, Glen Scrivener and John Richards, President of Atheism UK. Recorded live at St Michael's School in Aylesbury (thanks to Aylesbury Youth For Christ), the debate asks: Does Christianity provide the moral foundation of the West? Glen argues that Western values‚Äîsuch as equality and compassion‚Äîare shaped by 2,000 years of Christian influence. John counters that morality evolved naturally and religion often fuels division. From ancient Rome to Richard Dawkins, from the Good Samaritan to scientific discovery, this is a passionate exchange that pulls no punches.

title: What Did Christianity Give Us and Can We Live Without It? Paul Kingsnorth vs Bijan Omrani
description:
Historian Bijan Omrani, author of God is an Englishman, and acclaimed writer and former environmental activist Paul Kingsnorth, who converted to Christianity after exploring Wicca and Zen, join host Andy Kind for a powerful conversation about spiritual hunger in post-Christian Britain.
From the collapse of church attendance to a resurgence in young people seeking truth, this episode explores what we lose when a civilisation forgets its sacred roots ‚Äî and whether something is stirring in the dry bones of English Christianity.
We also draw on ideas from Tom Holland, Steven Bartlett, and Ayaan Hirsi Ali to ask: Is Christianity in England dead ‚Äî or just sleeping?

title: Is It Still Reasonable to Believe in God in the 21st Century? | Inspiring Philosophy vs Sam McKee
description:
In this special Unbelievable? schools debate, Christian apologist Mike Jones (@inspiringphilosophy) debates science philosopher and cancer researcher Sam McKee in front of students at Henry Floyd Grammar School thanks to Aylesbury Youth For Christ. Hosted by comedian and writer Andy Kind, this sharp and entertaining exchange tackles one of the most googled questions of our time: Is It Still Reasonable to Believe in God in the 21st Century? Expect DNA resetting,¬†AI, Mars colonies, and the future of faith on the podcast, and the rationality of believing in God in an age of accelerating science and technology?

Questions to ponder: Does science points¬†toward¬†or¬†away¬†from God? What kind of faith (if any) survives on Mars? What is the role of¬†religion in mental health and human flourishing? Does¬†objective morality¬†or¬†consciousness¬†point to a divine source? And if¬†Christianity is falsifiable‚Äîwould time travel to 1st century Jerusalem disprove it? title: God, AI and the Search for Meaning: Prof John Lennox and Dr John Vervaeke
description:
What does it mean to be truly human in an age of artificial intelligence, declining religious belief, and rising spiritual hunger? Oxford mathematician and Christian apologist Professor John Lennox and cognitive scientist Dr John Vervaeke of the University of Toronto, explore whether AI threatens or reveals our uniqueness, if meaning can exist without God, and whether spiritual transformation is possible in a post-religious age.

They discuss:
The Logos: Emergent or Eternal?
Can AI ever be conscious?
Why apocalyptic fears echo ancient longings?
Whether non-theistic spirituality can truly transform us?
And whether AI heralds the End Times?

Lennox draws from his new book, God, AI and the End of History SHOP HERE: https://amzn.to/3U9rR2q
to make the case for a classical Christian worldview grounded in hope, love, and reason.

title: Is Empathy a Sin? Can caring too much ever become morally wrong? Joe Rigney and Alastair Roberts
description:
Joe Rigney calls empathy a sin. Alastair Roberts says not so fast. Who‚Äôs right?
Today we explore a question at the heart of pastoral care, public witness, and Christian leadership: Is empathy a virtue to be cultivated or a vice to be resisted?¬† 

Andy Kind was joined by Professor Joe Rigney and Dr Alastair Roberts. Joe is the author of The Sin of Empathy, a provocative work that argues when empathy becomes "untethered" from truth, it ceases to be a virtue and can even become sinful.¬† Alastair, a fellow theologian, has written a substantial critique, arguing that Joe's language has muddied important distinctions and potentially misrepresents a vital Christian posture.¬† This conversation is not about labels, but substance‚Äîand we'll explore everything from scriptural foundations to gender roles, pastoral ethics, and theological nuance.¬†Can caring too much ever become morally wrong?

Dr Joe Rigney¬†serves as Fellow of Theology at New Saint Andrews College and the author of a number of books, including¬†Things of Earth¬†and¬†Strangely Bright. Joe Rigney Dr.¬†Joe¬†Rigney, author of¬†The Sin of Empathy. 
Joe on X: ¬†@joe_rigney

Dr Alastair¬†Roberts¬†is a Teaching Fellow of The Theopolis Institute and professor for Davenant Hall, and one of the hosts of the Mere Fidelity podcast. He is a co-author of¬†Echoes of Exodus: Tracing Themes of Redemption Through Scripture¬†(2018). 
Alistair's substack: https://argosy.substack.com/.
Alistair on X: @zugzwanged
on Radiopaper: https://radiopaper.com/AlastairRoberts

Podcast recorded in London and hosted by public philosopher¬†Jack Symes, four leading thinkers including @CosmicSkeptic  explore the origins and future of ethical thought.

From the role of emotions in our moral choices to the ethics of animal rights and cross-cultural disagreements, this conversation tackles one of humanity‚Äôs most enduring questions:¬†what does it mean to be good?

description:

They reflect on¬†Jesus as an asylum seeker, the church‚Äôs role in holding authorities accountable, and why¬†humility, wisdom, and spiritual responsibility¬†are key in navigating life‚Äôs biggest questions.

There is plenty of theology in Jewish culture about delay. Tom Wright has suggested that Paul would not have been surprised by the Lord‚Äôs 'delay' in returning. But if Paul had known that Christ‚Äôs return would still not have happened 2,000 years later, would it have altered his theology or pastoral urgency? Tom Wright also discusses why some people are born into a half-truncated version of Christianity and some not.

title: Can Therapy Heal the Soul? Two Psychiatrists Treating BPD & NPD Explore the Search for Meaning
description:
Today we‚Äôre asking: Can therapy heal the soul? We‚Äôll be exploring two complex and often misunderstood conditions - borderline personality disorder (BPD) and narcissistic personality disorder (NPD) - through both Christian and secular perspectives. What happens when psychiatry meets philosophy? And how do meaning, identity, and belief shape the path to healing?

Joining Vince Vitale on Unbelievable? are two leading psychiatrists from the Gunderson Residence at McLean Hospital in Massachusetts‚ÄîDr Brandon Unruh and Dr Claire Brickell. As colleagues, friends of over 15 years, and thoughtful practitioners, they each bring distinct perspectives to the complex work of treating borderline personality disorder (BPD) and narcissistic personality disorder (NPD)‚Äîexploring how therapy, identity, and belief intersect in the search for meaning.

For more on Dr. Unruh:

title: Does Nature point towards Design or Randomness? Rachel G. Jordan vs Michael Shermer
description:
Does Nature Point Towards Design or Randomness? with Rachel G. Jordan vs Michael Shermer

Is the awe-inspiring complexity of the natural world evidence of divine design‚Äîor simply the result of random evolutionary processes?
In this thought-provoking episode of Premier Unbelievable?, host Andy Kind is joined by two compelling voices from opposite sides of the science-faith conversation.

üîπ Rachel G. Jordan (who is incorrectly supered as "Dr." in this episode contacted us - once this show went live - to say she is not yet a PhD. Apologies for our error dear viewer) is a marine biologist and Christian author whose new book If the Ocean Has a Soul explores how marine life and ecology deepen her theological understanding. Drawing on her experiences with coral reefs, sea creatures, and scriptural insight, Rachel offers a spiritually rich view of the natural world.
 üì≤ Find her work at: https://rachelgjordan.com

üîπ Dr Michael Shermer is a sceptic, science historian, and founder of Skeptic Magazine. A bestselling author of The Moral Arc and Why People Believe Weird Things, Michael argues that reason and science‚Äînot religion‚Äîare the real drivers of progress and understanding.
 üî¨ Explore more at: https://www.skeptic.com

Together, they explore:
 üî∏ Whether nature reveals divine purpose or reflects impersonal forces
 üî∏ The soul, biblical stories, truth, and scientific inquiry
 üî∏ Suffering, beauty, and redemption from opposing worldviews
 üî∏ Awe, the hero‚Äôs journey, the gospel, and environmental care
 üî∏ Sea creatures, storytelling, and the limits of scepticism

Can awe lead to belief? Does randomness rule the universe?
 Dive into this rich, respectful conversation on faith, science, and the mystery of existence.

title: Does True Freedom Exist? Max Jeganathan vs Andrew Copson ‚Ä¢ Hosted by Andy Kind
description:
Is our obsession with personal autonomy leading to fulfilment‚Äî or fracture?  Max Jeganathan (author of The Freedom Trap) and Andrew Copson (CEO of Humanists UK) explore the purpose, power, and pitfalls of freedom. While Max argues that unexamined individualism breeds anxiety, disconnection, and moral confusion, Andrew defends freedom as a means to happiness, but warns against excessive egoism. The discussion spans everything from Nazi resistance and speeding laws to Taylor Swift and tech billionaires, with surprising agreements and sharp disagreements - particularly over the value of self-sacrifice and whether belief in God really matters. A nuanced, often humourous journey through politics, ethics and belief hosted by comedian and writer Andy Kind, this episode asks: is true freedom found in autonomy, or in responsibility, community and even love?

Andrew Copson is Chief Executive of Humanists UK and the current President of Humanists International. His books include The Little Book of Humanism (2020) and The Little Book of Humanist Weddings (2021) with Alice Roberts; Secularism: A Very Short Introduction (Oxford University Press, 2019); and The Wiley-Blackwell Handbook of Humanism (2015) with A. C. Grayling.
Bluesky: @andrewcopson
Facebook: @mrandrewcopson

Priyan Max Jeganathan is a speaker and writer for the Centre for Public Christianity in Australia. Max is a former lawyer and political and policy adviser. He has spoken at universities including the University of Oxford and Imperial College and at global businesses including Goldman Sachs, Lego, Nike, Samsung and Amazon. 
His new book: 
The Freedom Trap explores the nature, power, beauty and trappings of freedom - SHOP HERE:  https://amzn.to/4df6cOW

title: Jesus' Jewish identity, Paul's commands to women and Bonhoeffer's dilemma: Tom Wright answers
description:
Tom Wright and Mike Bird delve into the Jewish identity of Jesus in this week's episode of the Ask NT Wright Anything podcast. They respond to a listener's question about Paul's instructions in 1 Corinthians 11 and reflect on the moral dilemmas faced by Dietrich Bonhoeffer during the Nazi regime. 

With depth and clarity, they explore how seeing Jesus within his Jewish context enriches our understanding of the gospel, why Paul's words on worship remain controversial, and how Bonhoeffer's bold choices continue to challenge the church on questions of Biblical ethics, justice, and what role Christians should take on opposing tyranny.

00:41 Why did the God of the Universe choose to operate through a Jewish Messiah? Why was Jesus a Jew?
08:00 What does 1 Corinthians 11 mean for public worship, both contextually and how is it relevant today? 
17:36 What role should Christians take in opposing Tyranny? Was Bonhoeffer right to try and assassinate Hitler? What does this mean in line with the sin of murder?

title: Cancer, War & The God Question: Why So Much Suffering? Prof Richard Norman vs Sara Stevenson
description:
Why does a good God allow violence and suffering ‚Äî even in the Bible?

In this episode of Premier Unbelievable?, Andy Kind hosts a thought-provoking debate between humanist philosopher Richard Norman and Christian thinker Sara Stevenson from OCCA, The Oxford Centre For Christian Apologetics.

Together, they explore whether divine violence in the Old Testament undermines the credibility of Christianity, and whether humanists can offer a satisfying response to the reality of suffering. Is suffering ultimately arbitrary in a godless universe? Or does the biblical story offer a deeper hope in the face of pain and injustice?

Join us for a challenging and honest conversation on faith, morality, meaning, and the problem of evil. And for more on God and divine violence check out top scholar Tom NT Wright's Ask NT Wright Anything podcast here https://www.premier.plus/ask-nt-wright-anything/podcasts/episodes

Subscribe to Premier Unbelievable? for more debates and discussions at the intersection of faith and culture.

title: Does Tom Wright consider belief in the bodily resurrection of Jesus essential to Christian faith?
description:
What is church membership really for? Why does the bodily resurrection matter so much to Christian faith? And how should Christians respond to the suffering in Gaza?

In this episode of¬†Ask NT Wright Anything, Tom Wright and Mike Bird explore the theological roots of church membership, unpack the meaning of worship as a response to grace, and reflect on the hope of resurrection. They also discuss how lament is not just permitted but essential in a world full of pain, and why the church cannot remain silent in the face of injustice.

üéß Whether you're wrestling with the meaning of belonging, curious about resurrection, or grieving the suffering in the world, this conversation offers wisdom, comfort, and a challenge to live out the gospel in community and hope.

00:48:16 Where is 'church membership' in the Bible?
07:15:16 Is belief in the bodily resurrection crucial to salvation? 
18:22:16 Why does God need our worship? Does He demand it of us?
25:23:18 Where is God in the Gaza conflict? How should we respond to the suffering of the war as Christians, and how is God sovereign in all the conflict?

title: Is the Problem of Suffering the strongest argument against God? David Robertson vs Stephen Law
description:
Can the reality of suffering disprove a good God? Oxford Philosopher¬†Dr. Stephen Law¬†and Christian minister¬†Rev. David Robertson¬†debate the¬†problem of evil, the¬†evil God hypothesis, and whether suffering is evidence for or against theism. 

Does Christianity provide a meaningful answer, or does the sheer amount of suffering make belief in God irrational?

Law presents the evidential problem of evil and his ‚Äúevil God‚Äù challenge. At the same time, Robertson defends the Christian view that suffering can be reconciled with a loving God through free will, morality, and the hope found in Christ. From the nature of evil to the philosophical implications of faith and atheism, this thought-provoking conversation tackles one of life‚Äôs biggest questions.

**** Please note: In this video, David is incorrectly labeled as "Dr." in the on-screen captions. His correct title is "Rev." We apologize for the oversight and wanted to clarify.

title: Easter Special: NT Wright on the Resurrection: History, Theology & Why It Still Matters
description:
This Easter, Tom Wright and theologian Mike Bird explore the bold claim at the heart of Christianity: that Jesus truly rose from the dead. Mike raises the modern skepticism - how can we believe in resurrection when we know dead people don‚Äôt come back? Tom offers a robust response rooted in Jewish messianic hope, early Christian belief, and the bodily resurrection as essential to the identity of Jesus.

They unpack key Scriptures, contrast Gnostic and early Christian views, and delve into why the resurrection affirms creation, love, and God's ultimate victory.

üìå This is part one of a two-part conversation. In part two, Tom discusses the real-world implications of the resurrection for the Church and Christian mission today. That part is for Ask NT Wright Anything subscribers only.

üëâ To access the final part of the discussion and support the show, visit AskNTWright.com

title: Did Jesus Really Die and Rise from the Dead? David Instone-Brewer vs Ijaz Ahmed with Andy Kind
description:
As we head into the Easter weekend, we ask: Is the resurrection central to the Christian faith? How are the death and resurrection of Jesus understood in both Christianity and Islam? We‚Äôll be examining the historical and theological claims of Christianity regarding the crucifixion, resurrection, and divinity of Jesus with Rev Dr David Instone-Brewer is a retired Bible scholar and former Research Fellow at Tyndale House, Cambridge. Joining him from Canada is Islamic apologist Ijaz Ahmed, who challenges with Islamic perspectives on these claims.
From how Jesus is viewed in Islamic theology and history, to the different interpretations of the crucifixion and resurrection, we‚Äôll look at the historical evidence for the resurrection of Jesus. Is it a well-supported historical event, or a later theological invention?

title: God‚Äôs Love: universal, personal, or both? NT Wright Answers
description:
Does God love us personally, or just humanity as a whole? How do we experience His love in a broken church? What does it mean to draw near to God, and how do marriage and parental blessings fit into the life of faith?

0:00 ‚Äì Welcome & today‚Äôs big questions
0:34 ‚Äì What do Christians mean when they say ‚ÄúGod loves you‚Äù?
2:17 ‚Äì Does God actually have feelings of love?
4:05 ‚Äì Does God love me personally or just ‚Äúhumanity‚Äù?
6:23 ‚Äì A shocking idea: a God who really loves the world
10:02 ‚Äì ‚ÄúI am loved, therefore I am‚Äù ‚Äì identity reshaped
11:14 ‚Äì Stuck in a flawed church ‚Äì should I stay or leave?
15:01 ‚Äì Which disagreements are worth splitting a church over?
18:56 ‚Äì Unity vs truth: when is it right to walk away?
21:42 ‚Äì Dawkins at Evensong?! Atheists, doubt & surprise belief
22:56 ‚Äì How N.T. Wright actually draws near to God daily
27:03 ‚Äì When you seek God and feel nothing
30:08 ‚Äì Is it ungodly to marry without your parents‚Äô blessing?
34:26 ‚Äì Wise counsel for love, family and faith
35:35 ‚Äì Wrap-up & how to send Tom your questions

In this episode of¬†Ask NT Wright Anything, Tom Wright and Mike Bird answer profound questions about God's love, both universal and personal, the dynamics of the church community ‚Äî its struggles and its strengths, and the ways we grow closer to God. They also discuss the role of parental guidance in marriage, tackling the tensions between cultural expectations and personal choices.
üéß If you've ever wondered how God's love works in real life, why the church can be both a challenge and a blessing, or how to navigate faith in relationships, this episode offers wisdom, encouragement, and biblical insight.

title: Culture Wars: have Christians lost the plot? with Ben Chang and Jonty Langley
description:
Are we trapped in an endless culture war? Have Christians become more focused on politics than the person of Jesus? Are terms like cancel culture and postmodernism helping us understand the world, or just fuelling division?

In this episode of¬†Unbelievable? host Andy Kind sits down with Ben Chang and Jonty Langley to dissect the heated battlegrounds of cancel culture, identity politics, and the Church‚Äôs role in these debates. Is cancel culture a necessary tool for accountability or a silencing mechanism? How should Christians engage with social justice and critical theory without losing sight of biblical truth? 

This week we're diving deep into theological perspectives, the authority of scripture, and the shifting dynamics of power, oppression, and justice in today‚Äôs world. Whether you‚Äôre wrestling with the intersection of faith and politics or questioning how culture shapes biblical interpretation, this discussion will challenge your thinking and offer new insights.

#culturewars #cancelled #progressivechristianity #criticaltheory 

For Ben Chang:
üéô Ben Chang, author of Christ and the Culture Wars is a speaker, writer and emergency doctor working in London. He speaks on a range of issues including bioethics, cultural engagement and identity politics

For Jonty Langley:
üéô Jonty Langley, editor of Shibboleth magazine & co-host of Beer Christianity
They debate faith, free speech, critical theory, and whether Christians are called to win arguments‚Äîor love their neighbour.

title: Is there good evidence to believe in God? Ed Atkinson vs Sara Stevenson hosted by Andy Kind
description:
Premier Unbelievable? Podcast is back in Aylesbury, UK at Sir Henry Floyd Grammar School with host Andy Kind moderating a debate on the existence of God, featuring Sara Stevenson from OCCA The Oxford Centre for Christian Apologetics and atheist Ed Atkinson, engineer and  former Christian turned Agnostic, and host of the Doubts Aloud podcast. 

Today's discussion dives into questions of morality, human value, and scientific methods for belief, addressing whether there is good evidence to believe in God. Sara presents a cumulative case for God's existence and goodness, while Ed scrutinises these through a lens of moral relativism and naturalism. In front of a hall full of teenagers the debaters explore philosophical and empirical arguments, interrogating deeply contested beliefs.

title: Does Science Point Toward or Away from God? Phil Halper vs. Prof. Paul Ewart (Oxford Physics)
description:
Today's episode filmed in front of a live audience of students at John Hampden Grammar School, High Wycombe, UK, seeks to answer the age-old question: Does science bring us closer to understanding a divine creator, or does it steer us away from such a belief?  Sam McKee, researcher and associate tutor in history and philosophy of science at Manchester Metropolitan University guest hosts and he is joined by two distinguished guests. 

Paul Ewart, an Emeritus Fellow of Worcester College, Oxford. He has served as an Associate Professor in the Department of Physics. His research areas include fundamental atomic physics, quantum and nonlinear optics, and the design of novel lasers for spectroscopy. He has also focused on developing new techniques for optical diagnostics and gas-sensing for environmental monitoring.

Debating with Paul is Phil Halper, a YouTuber who has interviewed many of the world's leading scientists, including Stephen Hawking, Roger Penrose, and Alan Guth. Phil is a Fellow of the Royal Astronomical Society and was appointed journalist in residence at the Penn State Institute for Gravitation and the Cosmos. He has been the lead author on several peer-reviewed papers in fields ranging from cosmology to neuroscience and philosophy. Phil's first book, 'Battle of the Big Bang: The New Tales of our Cosmic Origins,' co-authored with award-winning cosmologist Niayesh Afshordi, will be published by the University of Chicago Press in the spring of 2025.

So listen below as Paul Ewart and Phil Halper engage in a compelling debate exploring the profound question: Does science point toward or away from God?  Guest hosted by Dr. Sam McKee.

title: Islamic blasphemy law in Britain? Andy Bannister and Tim Dieppe hosted by Andy Kind
description:
As the UK government announced the launch of a new Islamophobia council to define ‚Äòanti-Muslim hatred/ Islamophobia‚Äô on February 28th, the start of Ramadan, one thing is clear: This is a hot-button issue that raises serious questions about free speech, blasphemy laws, and the balance between protecting religious sensibilities and upholding open dialogue in a liberal society.
0:00 ‚Äî Why Islamophobia Is Exploding as a Debate in Britain

title: NT Wright explains common misconceptions about the resurrection and apostleship
description:
In this episode of Ask NT Wright Anything, Tom and Mike dive into two foundational topics: the resurrection and the role of apostles in the early church.

What did first-century Jews believe about resurrection? Tom responds to William Lane Craig‚Äôs argument that individual resurrections weren‚Äôt expected before the End Times. He unpacks how Jesus‚Äô resurrection differs from all others, marking the beginning of God‚Äôs new creation.
What makes someone an 'Apostle'? The discussion explores Paul‚Äôs apostleship, the fluid roles of teachers, prophets, and elders, and the importance of apostolic succession in church leadership.

üí° Key Topics this week:
 Did first-century Jews expect individual resurrections?
 Jesus vs. Lazarus‚Äîwhat makes Christ‚Äôs resurrection unique?
 The role of an apostle‚Äîwas Paul truly one?
 Apostolic succession‚Äîdoes church authority really trace back to the apostles?

¬†Theological significance of Jesus‚Äô lineage¬†in Israel‚Äôs story

title: Ask NT Wright Anything: Is Salvation for everyone? Predestination, Free Will and Inclusion Theology
description:
Tom Wright and Dr. Mike Bird dive into deep theological questions in this episode, tackling Inclusion Theology, Universalism, Predestination, and the question of Free Will. 

üí°¬†Is Salvation universally available? Does predestination mean some are excluded? How do free will and God‚Äôs purposes coexist?¬†Tom and Mike unpack these complex questions, shedding light on biblical perspectives that emphasize transformation, assurance, and the church‚Äôs role in reflecting God‚Äôs image in the world.

Key themes in today's episode:
Why determinism vs. free will is often a misleading debate.
How predestination is about God‚Äôs purpose, not exclusion.
The Holy Spirit‚Äôs role in salvation and human responsibility.
Why the New Testament presents salvation as both universal and personal.
The Biblical view of the soul vs. Platonic philosophy.

üéß If you‚Äôve ever wrestled with questions about election, inclusion, or what it means to be human in God‚Äôs plan, this episode offers fresh insights to challenge and encourage your faith.

title: Is the Universe Fine-Tuned for Life?¬†Luke Barnes vs Martin Bauer hosted by Philip Goff at Durham Uni
description:
Is the universe fine-tuned for life? And does physics point to God? ¬†Tune in to the Unbelievable? Podcast for our debate this week which was filmed in front of a live audience at the University of Durham, with Prof. Philip Goff moderating.¬†

We have two excellent physicists in the hot seats. Dr Luke Barnes is a senior lecturer at Western Sydney University and has published extensively on the fine tuning of physics for life. On the other side we have Dr Martin Bauer an associate professor in physics from Durham University, UK. Martin's research focuses on dark matter, and Higgs physics to name just two. 

This debate at Durham University was funded by the panpsychism and panentheism three year project that Philip Goff and Andre Buchareth run at Durham University, which is currently funded by the John Templeton Foundation.¬†

title: Is the Universe 5-mins old? Dan Linford vs David Lu debate Big Bang and KalƒÅm Cosmological Argument!
description:
How do we know the age of the Universe, really? Today's guest suggests atheists should believe our world is actually 5 minutes old‚Ä¶ no, seriously!!

In this episode,¬†Vince Vitale¬†hosts a fascinating discussion with¬†David Lu¬†and¬†Dan Linford¬†to explore a groundbreaking theory and its philosophical and scientific implications on the Big Bang, the existence of a Creator, and the age of the universe.

David Lu¬†presents a novel argument suggesting the universe might only be five minutes old, challenging traditional cosmological beliefs. This bold claim ignites a lively debate on causation, time, and the very nature of existence. Dan Linford¬†counters with philosophical and scientific perspectives, leading to a deep exploration of topics such as:

üîπ The nature of space-time and causation
üîπ Probability distributions of cosmic events and the Boltzmann brain problem
üîπ Empirical evidence vs. theoretical claims about the universe's age
üîπ The validity of cosmological dating methods

Together, they unpack whether the universe‚Äôs beginning requires a cause and explore how the interplay of science and philosophy shapes our understanding of reality.

title: Should I be Catholic or Anglican? Ask NT Wright Anything
description:
Dr. Mike Bird and Tom NT Wright take us on a deeply personal journey through their denominational journeys in today's episode of the podcast. From Anglican roots to Catholic insights, they explore the rich tapestry of Christian traditions and reflect on how faith evolves across life‚Äôs seasons.

üí° Together, they tackle a listener's heartfelt dilemma: navigating faith within a family where religious backgrounds differ. Should you join the Catholic Church or embrace a Reformed tradition? Tom and Mike unpack this complex decision, emphasizing the role of conscience, community, and theological understanding in shaping one‚Äôs spiritual path.
The discussion also dives into the transformative doctrine of justification, examining the interplay of faith, works, and the Holy Spirit in the believer's life. Unity among Christians and the ongoing sanctification process are central themes, offering fresh perspectives for anyone wrestling with denominational differences or seeking deeper theological insight.

‚ú®¬†Highlights include:
Tom Wright's reflections on growing up Anglican and its profound impact on his theology. Mike Bird‚Äôs vibrant denominational journey, from Baptist beginnings to his embrace of Anglicanism. A breakdown of Catholic and Protestant views on justification, faith, and works. The unifying power of the Holy Spirit in the global Church.

üëâ Whether you‚Äôre exploring your own denominational identity, facing family faith tensions, or yearning for a better understanding of Christian unity, this episode is packed with wisdom to inspire and challenge you.

title: Does God Exist? The Ontological Argument Debate ü§î‚ú®
description:
Theologian Dr Gavin Ortlund vs Agnostic Joe Schmid

In this thought-provoking episode of¬†Premier Unbelievable, host¬†Vince Vitale¬†is joined by two brilliant minds to unpack the¬†Ontological Argument¬†for the existence of God: ‚ú® Dr. Gavin Ortlund¬†‚Äì President of¬†@TruthUnites , theologian, author, and YouTuber üéì Joe Schmid¬†‚Äì Philosophy PhD student at Princeton, metaphysics expert, creator of¬†@MajestyofReason  and @AlexOConnor 's favourite young agnostic. 

In this thought-provoking episode, we explore:
üîπ¬†Anselm's famous ontological argument¬†and its philosophical legacy
üîπ¬†A priori reasoning¬†and what it means for theology and metaphysics
üîπ¬†Modal arguments¬†and the concepts of necessary vs. contingent existence
üîπ Critiques, including¬†Kant‚Äôs objections¬†and¬†parody arguments

This dynamic conversation unpacks the complexities of¬†God‚Äôs existence, philosophical rationality, and the¬†nature of being¬†itself. Whether you're a philosopher, theologian, or curious skeptic, this episode will challenge your perspective and expand your understanding. üååüìö

Meet the Guests:
1Ô∏è‚É£¬†Joe Schmid
Joe is a Philosophy PhD student at¬†Princeton University, specializing in¬†metaphysics¬†and¬†philosophy of religion. He has co-authored the¬†Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy¬†entry on ontological arguments and written two books:¬†Existential Inertia and Classical Theistic Proofs¬†and¬†The Majesty of Reason. On his YouTube channel,¬†Majesty of Reason, Joe creates lectures and hosts philosophical discussions.

Gavin is the President of¬†Truth Unites, a theologian, and author of nine books, including¬†Why God Makes Sense in a World That Doesn‚Äôt¬†and¬†What It Means to Be Protestant. He holds a PhD in¬†historical theology¬†from Fuller Seminary and is a fellow of several esteemed organizations, including the Keller Center for Cultural Apologetics. Gavin also shares content on theology, apologetics, and church history through his YouTube channel,¬†Truth Unites.

title: Does Christianity need to recover its confidence?
description:
with Rupert Shortt and Nick Spencer.

Towards the end of this discussion, Roger Bolton's guests acknowledge a profound hunger for Christianity. So, how did we get here? How can Christianity recover its confidence? Have Christian leaders, in their pursuit of relevance, lost sight of the true distinctiveness of what it means to be a follower of Jesus Christ?

This episode of the Unbelievable? podcast delves into the evolving role of Christianity with distinguished guests Nick Spencer, Senior Fellow at the Theos think tank, and Rupert Shortt, acclaimed author and journalist. Together, they explore some of the most pressing questions about faith in the modern age:

How has Christianity shaped Western values like morality, equality, and human rights?
What is the faith's relationship with science and secularism?
Can Christianity remain relevant in an increasingly multicultural and secular world?
The discussion unpacks themes of cultural amnesia, media misrepresentation, and the rising spiritual hunger among younger generations. Is Christianity truly in decline, or is there a path to renewal?

For today's guests:

In a world filled with questions about faith, truth, and the future, can¬†Islam¬†and¬†Christianity¬†find common ground, or do their beliefs reveal irreconcilable differences? Dr. Andy Bannister, a Christian apologist and author, and Abdullah Al Andalusi, an Islamic thinker and activist, go head to head in this week's episode of the Unbelievable?¬†Podcast - coming together for a powerful discussion on the big questions shaping our world today.

Do Muslims and Christians worship the same God?How do Islamic and Christian beliefs shape our understanding of¬†life, purpose, and truth?What happens when faith influences¬†technology¬†and the future of¬†AI?What unique visions of humanity's future do Islam and Christianity have to offer?

title: Evolution debate
description:
Dr Francis Collins debates atheist scientist Phil Halper on the Unbelievable Podcast

In a world splintered by distrust across science, faith, and politics, is it possible to find common ground on the sources of true wisdom? Dr. Francis Collins, a world-renowned geneticist and Christian, believes we must, and his new book, The Road to Wisdom: On Truth, Science, Faith, and Trust, aims to rekindle these values. Collins argues that a foundation of humility, truth, and morality ‚Äî not partisan loyalty ‚Äî should guide our judgement. But in an age where allegiance often outweighs evidence, can this vision truly take hold?

In this episode of Premier Unbelievable, Collins squares off with Phil Halper, atheist scientist and creator of Before the Big Bang, to probe the limits of science and the necessity of faith. 

Together, they‚Äôll tackle pressing questions: 
Can faith and science coexist without compromising truth? How does trust (or lack of it) contribute to today‚Äôs social and political divides?Is it possible to transcend polarization and rebuild a fractured world?
Whether you're a person of faith, a skeptic, or simply searching for answers in a turbulent world, this episode offers a deep dive into the limits of science, the necessity of trust, and the pursuit of wisdom. Can Collins' vision inspire change, or are we too entrenched to move forward?
